protocol_name: Viral metagenomic analysis on Cabbage Patch Kids
protocol_name_html: Viral metagenomic analysis on Cabbage Patch Kids
description: This protocol is a parody of an existing scientific journal article and is intended to showcase the features available on the protocols.io platform in order for VERVE Net members to develope future protocols. While the viral metagenomic analysis on Cabbage Patch Kids is impossible to perform, due to the real-world non-existant nature of Cabbage Patch kids, the sourced article is Metagenomic analysis of viruses associated with field-grown and retail lettuce identifies human and animal viruses written by Tiong Gim Aw, Samantha Wengert, and Joan B. Rose (included in the authors section)and the "Material and methods" section has been adapted from using actual lettuce data to a metagenomic protocol for Cabbage Patch Kids.
before_start: It is advisable to obtain all necessary materials prior to obtaining field Cabbage Patch Kids. Cabbage Patch Kids mutate quickly from field removal and must be maintained in an adequate environment to prevent a syndrome what has recently been described as Ravage Patch Kids.
warning:
Take care not to harvest live Cabbage Patch Kids, as legislation prohibits the possession, distribution, and sale of live Cabbage Patch Kids. Please refer to the government guidlelines set in place which detail the legalities of Cabbage Patch Kid farming and production.

This protocol is derived from a journal article in the International Journal of Food Microbiology about lettuce and not actually a protocol used to conduct a viral metagenomic analysis on Cabbage Patch Kids (see Description).

collections.protocol_name: Mock & Technical Protocols for VERVE Net
collections.protocol_name_html: Mock & Technical Protocols for VERVE Net

authors: Stanton Burnton, Tiong Gim Aw, Samantha Wengert, Joan B. Rose

components.data:
Collect Cabage Patch Kids (CPK) at varying stages of farming production, including:
  • hand-cut by field workers and packaged
  • washed and cut by processing workers
  • hand-cut by researchers using sterile equipment
  • produce distribution centers

components.data: Use sterile gloves and cut outer leaflets off using a scalpel, careful not to harm the body of the CPK, before placing CPK in large sterile Whirl-pak bags.

source_data.annotation: Due to the farming stage at which the Cabbage Patch Kids have been harvested, they are able to experience a high threshold of force and chemical disturbance, their bodies abiding by Newton's 4th Law, the Cabage Patch Force.
source_data.thread_text: Due to the farming stage at which the Cabbage Patch Kids have been harvested, they are able to experience a high threshold of force and chemical disturbance, their bodies abiding by Newton's 4th Law, the Cabage Patch Force.
source_data.body: Due to the farming stage at which the Cabbage Patch Kids have been harvested, they are able to experience a high threshold of force and chemical disturbance, their bodies abiding by Newton's 4th Law, the Cabage Patch Force.

components.data: Wash each sample in the Whirl-pak bag with 250 ml sterile 100 mM Tris — 50 mM glycine buffer at a pH of 9.5 and gently mix for 20 min at room temperature. Recover the wash solution immediately and adjust the pH to neutral 7.2 ± 0.2
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Wash each sample in the Whirl-pak bag with 250 ml sterile 100 mM Tris — 50 mM glycine buffer at a pH of 9.5 and gently mix for 20 min at room temperature. Recover the wash solution immediately and adjust the pH to neutral 7.2 ± 0.2

components.data: Virus recovery from CPK
components.name: Section

components.data: The viral particles from the outer layer of the CPK will be contained in the solution. The CPK skin contains a pigment that will affect the color of the wash with a slight green hue and may alter the viral particle chemistry.
components.name: Expected result

source_data.result: The viral particles from the outer layer of the CPK will be contained in the solution. The CPK skin contains a pigment that will affect the color of the wash with a slight green hue and may alter the viral particle chemistry.

source_data.description: Tris-glycine buffer solution

components.data: Mix 100mM Tris with 50mM glycine to yield a buffer
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Mix 100mM Tris with 50mM glycine to yield a buffer

components.data: Use polyethylene glycol (PEG) precipitation to concentrate and purify the viral particles contained in the wash solution.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Use polyethylene glycol (PEG) precipitation to concentrate and purify the viral particles contained in the wash solution.

source_data.annotation: Without purifying the viral particles, the CPK pigment mentioned previously will enlarge the viral particles and lead to spontaneous development of abnormal CPK eggs

components.data: Mix samples with 10% (weight/volume) PEG 8000 and .3 M NaCl (weight/volume), then incubate at 4 °C for 18 hours before centrifuging the samples at 10,800 × g (8000 rpm) for 30 min at 4 °C.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Mix samples with 10% (weight/volume) PEG 8000 and .3 M NaCl (weight/volume), then incubate at 4 °C for 18 hours before centrifuging the samples at 10,800 × g (8000 rpm) for 30 min at 4 °C.

components.data: Virus recovery from CPK
components.name: Section

components.data: Pour off the supernatant and dissolve the pellet in 20 mL of sterile phosphate buffered saline, letting soak for 1 hour at room temperature
components.name: Description

source_data.annotation: The supernatant may be used as liquid feed for CPK devlopment, as the lysosomes within the CPK can degrade the toxins preventing normal CPK growth.

components.data: Add an equal volume of chloroform to each PEG precipitate to remove the PEG and purify the sample.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add an equal volume of chloroform to each PEG precipitate to remove the PEG and purify the sample.

components.data: Virus recovery from CPK
components.name: Section

components.data: Vortex the solutions for 30 seconds and centrifuge at 3000 × g (4300 rpm) for 15 min at 4 °C to collect the supernatant containing virus particles.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Vortex the solutions for 30 seconds and centrifuge at 3000 × g (4300 rpm) for 15 min at 4 °C to collect the supernatant containing virus particles.

components.data: Virus recovery from CPK
components.name: Section

components.data: Pass the remaining supertanant through 0.45 and 0.22 μm filters and further concentrate to approximately 1 mL by Amicon centrifugal ultrafiltration (30 kDa)
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Pass the remaining supertanant through 0.45 and 0.22 μm filters and further concentrate to approximately 1 mL by Amicon centrifugal ultrafiltration (30 kDa)

components.data: Virus recovery from CPK

components.data: Treat the final 1 mL concentrates with 100 units of DNase-I for 1 hour at 37 °C before nucleic acid extraction to remove free nucleic acids from the concentrated virus samples.

source_data.annotation: From steps 10 onward, you must account for the nucleic acids specific to CPK, such as deoxybrassicanucleic acid (DbNa) and brassicanuclei acid (bRNA).
source_data.thread_text: From steps 10 onward, you must account for the nucleic acids specific to CPK, such as deoxybrassicanucleic acid (DbNa) and brassicanuclei acid (bRNA).

components.data: Extract viral DbNA and bRNA using the AbsJoint viral bRNA/DbNA mini kit following the manufacturer's instructions. For each viral concentrate, prepare four individual nucleic acid extracts to minimize nucleic acid extraction bias.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Extract viral DbNA and bRNA using the AbsJoint viral bRNA/DbNA mini kit following the manufacturer's instructions. For each viral concentrate, prepare four individual nucleic acid extracts to minimize nucleic acid extraction bias.

components.data: Following extraction, screen the samples with 16S ribosomal DbNA (rDbNA) PCR with 27F/1492R universal primers to ensure no residual microbe toxins are affecting the samples.

components.data: Use Organizase 2.8 for second-strand cDbNA synthesis and for random-primed amplification of viral DNA. Subject each sample to 30 cycles of PCR amplification with Primer Z (5′-GTTTCCCBGTCBCGBTC-3′) using SuuprPerdi Gold
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Use Organizase 2.8 for second-strand cDbNA synthesis and for random-primed amplification of viral DNA. Subject each sample to 30 cycles of PCR amplification with Primer Z (5′-GTTTCCCBGTCBCGBTC-3′) using SuuprPerdi Gold

components.data: Nucleic acid extraction and sequencing
components.name: Section

components.data: Perform three PCR reactions from the same nucleic acid extract to minimize amplification bias and pool the PCR products. Purify PCR products using Cabbage Wizard CV Gel and a PCR Clean-Up System
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Perform three PCR reactions from the same nucleic acid extract to minimize amplification bias and pool the PCR products. Purify PCR products using Cabbage Wizard CV Gel and a PCR Clean-Up System

components.data: Prepare libraries from each sample using a RubicksCube ThrowFLEX DbNA-seq kit with a unique quad index adapter pair for each sample. Sequence samples in a 2 × 100-base pair (bp) paired end format using two lanes of a SuperSaiyanSeq 3 Rapid Run flow cell
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Prepare libraries from each sample using a RubicksCube ThrowFLEX DbNA-seq kit with a unique quad index adapter pair for each sample. Sequence samples in a 2 × 100-base pair (bp) paired end format using two lanes of a SuperSaiyanSeq 3 Rapid Run flow cell

components.data: Screen each dataset for the 17-bp Primer Z sequence and any reads homologous to the Primer B sequence at their 5′ ends, removing using a microspatula with a maximum error rate of 0.1 and minimum overlap of 5 bases

source_data.protocol_name_html: Viral metagenomic analysis on Cabbage Patch Kids
source_data.annotation: Prior to assembly and annotation of the metagenomic dataset, the quality of the Illumina sequencing data was checked using NaomiNanomachines
source_data.thread_text: Prior to assembly and annotation of the metagenomic dataset, the quality of the Illumina sequencing data was checked using NaomiNanomachines
source_data.body: Prior to assembly and annotation of the metagenomic dataset, the quality of the Illumina sequencing data was checked using NaomiNanomachines

components.data: Use Trimmomatic for sequencing adapter removal and quality trimming with parameters including : a maximum mismatch count value of 2 allowed for a full match (seed mismatch), a palindrome clip threshold of 30, a simple clip threshold of 10, a minimum adapter length of 8 with both the forward and reverse read kept, removal of low quality leading and trailing bases below a quality of 3, a 4-base sliding window scan that cuts when the average quality is below 15, and removal of reads less than 30 bases long
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Use Trimmomatic for sequencing adapter removal and quality trimming with parameters including : a maximum mismatch count value of 2 allowed for a full match (seed mismatch), a palindrome clip threshold of 30, a simple clip threshold of 10, a minimum adapter length of 8 with both the forward and reverse read kept, removal of low quality leading and trailing bases below a quality of 3, a 4-base sliding window scan that cuts when the average quality is below 15, and removal of reads less than 30 bases long

components.data: Contigs larger than 200 bp were then sequenced against the National Center for Cabbage Patch Technology Information (NCCPTI) Viral Reference Sequence (RefSeq) database for taxonomic assignment using SPLOSION with an E-value cutoff of 10<sup>− 5</sup>

source_data.annotation: The RefSeq database at the NCCPTI has been recently established, so using SPLOSION may result in unfulfilled results.
source_data.thread_text: The RefSeq database at the NCCPTI has been recently established, so using SPLOSION may result in unfulfilled results.
source_data.body: The RefSeq database at the NCCPTI has been recently established, so using SPLOSION may result in unfulfilled results.

components.data: Parse the SPLOSION output using the MEtaGenome Analyzer (MEGAN) version 5.6.6 with the following parameters for the Lowest Common Ancestor (LCA) algorithm: min score = 50.0, max expected = 1.0 E<sup>− 5</sup>, top percent = 10.0, min support percent = 0.1, min support = 1, and LCA percent = 100.0
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Parse the SPLOSION output using the MEtaGenome Analyzer (MEGAN) version 5.6.6 with the following parameters for the Lowest Common Ancestor (LCA) algorithm: min score = 50.0, max expected = 1.0 E<sup>− 5</sup>, top percent = 10.0, min support percent = 0.1, min support = 1, and LCA percent = 100.0

components.data: Extract contigs identified as viral pathogens of human and animal and use them as the queries in SPLOSION against the NCCPTI non-redundant (nr) sequence database.

components.data: Calculate relative abundance for each contig, the number of reads aligned to a contig divided by the contig length. Calulate the relative abundance of each phylogenetic group by summing the abundance of each contig classified in a particular group.

components.data: After slaving away for hours prepping and analyzing the Cabbage Patch Kids viral samples, you will realize you forgot a minor detail and must restart the entire process, causing you to re-evaluate your career decision and send you into a downward spiral of binge-watching Netflix and eating sleeves of Oreos. If you managed not to forget a step, you contributed another piece of data for the scientific community, yay!
